options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture was also an option.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Ability to make and analyze distributed algorithms
Learned about various consensus protocols for message passing and shared memory systems

The course studies message passing and shared memory models of distributed computation. For both models, the problem of fault tolerant consensus is explored at depth. For shared memory models, mutual exclusion and the wait-free hierarchy are also explored.

Basics of distributed system theory: Models of distributed systems (i.e., message-passing vs shared memory), algorithms for various synchronization and agreement tasks, proofs of correctness and complexity, and algorithm behavior under different types of failure.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Teaching very strong -- engaging, dynamic, and humorous teaching style, interesting content

Prof. Aspnes provides notes for the course, which I found very helpful. Students will most likely find themselves consulting the notes/textbook to fill in gaps or to understand how to make their arguments rigorous.

Professor Aspnes is an excellent lecturer. The subject matter is interesting from a CS perspective but would be dry if not for his teaching style, which is accessible without overdoing it. Definitely the best proof-centric instruction I've gotten.

On the other hand, while this isn't a flaw necessarily, you should be aware that this *is* a theory class. We did discuss particular algorithms and behaviors, but there's no implementation further than pseudocode, and problem sets (which are of a good difficulty but are maybe a bit too delayed from the class content) are entirely proof-style.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Attending lectures and office hours was sufficient to facilitate learning the material. However, for students who like to take extensive notes, it was probably difficult to write down everything because the professor would clear the board immediately after filling up a page. Waiting a few seconds after writing everything down would help those who are taking notes.

I felt like Professor Aspnes adapted pretty well to the online format, although I think the lack of a physical audience was hard for both him and us. All in all though, it didn't feel like there were many changes.

I should point out that there were no exams as a result of the pandemic, so the final grade was based entirely on problem sets. I think student opinions were divided on this - I liked it since I've had pretty bad experiences with online exams (especially proof-ish ones), but it did emphasize the problem sets a bit more than comfortable. Maybe a good compromise would be to have an additional problem set instead?

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely -- teaching is excellent and content is good

I would recommend this course to any student who is broadly interested in theoretical computer science. Knowledge of the techniques and tools in distributed computing is useful both in industry and in academia.
Yes, would recommend. It's a great option among the grad-level CS courses.
If Professor Aspnes is not the person grading your homework, this is a great class!
